title: A deletion polymorphism in the <italic>Caenorhabditis elegans</italic> RIG-I homolog disables viral RNA dicing and antiviral immunity
abstract: RNA interference defends against viral infection in plant and animal cells. The nematode <italic>Caenorhabditis elegans</italic> and its natural pathogen, the positive-strand RNA virus Orsay, have recently emerged as a new animal model of host-virus interaction. Using a genome-wide association study in <italic>C. elegans</italic> wild populations and quantitative trait locus mapping, we identify a 159 base-pair deletion in the conserved <italic>drh-1</italic> gene (encoding a RIG-I-like helicase) as a major determinant of viral sensitivity. We show that DRH-1 is required for the initiation of an antiviral RNAi pathway and the generation of virus-derived siRNAs (viRNAs). In mammals, RIG-I-domain containing proteins trigger an interferon-based innate immunity pathway in response to RNA virus infection. Our work in <italic>C. elegans</italic> demonstrates that the RIG-I domain has an ancient role in viral recognition. We propose that RIG-I acts as modular viral recognition factor that couples viral recognition to different effector pathways including RNAi and interferon responses.
